history.content:
CS/Math will help you much more for 2 Sigma and Jane Street. These are highly quantitative firms and they don't necessarily expect you to have any sort of finance background. I should note that I've gone through several quant trading interviews and they've never asked any sort of economics, investment, or finance questions. It's always programming, probability, statistics, general math, etc.

---

Just a note that Jane Street and Two Sigma aren't fintech firms. Jane Street is a prop shop and Two Sigma is a hedge fund. It's helpful to make this distinction because fintech has more to do with delivering financial services than managing investments.

This answer on Quora might help inform what classes you should be taking, from an MIT student who interned at Jump Trading: https://qr.ae/TWycgq

Approximately, 6.005 = parts of 61B / 61C; 6.035 = CS 164; 6.006 = 61B; 6.046 = 170; 6.041 = 1st half of EE126

---

Also, Citadel is running a competition at Berkeley in a few weeks you might be interested in: https://www.citadel.com/careers/the-data-open/apply/?apply_to=university-of-california-berkeley

children.subject: CS & Stats would be the best imo

I could write an essay on this topic as I used to be very set on quantitative finance. But that's neither here nor there.

My best and last piece of advice is to use the UC Berkeley network to talk directly to people in the industry. Do not be afraid to reach out to Berkeley alumni who work at Jane Street, Two Sigma, or any other firm you may be interested in. I've found that they are usually more than happy to speak with current students. Furthermore, they will give you the best information and resources as they are in the position you hope to find yourself in one day. Best of luck!

Thank you guys so much! I'm a first generation college student with no much exposure to all these resources or ways, and I really appreciate that so many helpful people can spend time thinking for me! I'm probably going to ask some of my professors and gsi's during office hour to get more info. Really appreciate it!

history.content:
Hi guys, 

I’m a sophomore interested in both economics and CS and a job at a fintech company like 2 sigma and Jane street would be my dream career.

But now I have a dilemma: I can either double major Econ and CS, or just major in CS/double Math with CS. The latter won’t give me much Econ training about finance, but it will enable me to take much more CS classes, potentially making me more qualified for the harder interviews at fintech firms. A double major in Econ would probably be easier, and I actually get to formally learn about investment, finance, etc, plus its something I enjoy learning as much as CS. 

So, anyone with similar career goals want to share their thoughts? Any help is appreciated!
history.subject: CS and Econ double major for Fintech job?
